title: Budweiser owner ready to raise stakes with new £70bn takeover offer for rival brewer
text:

Sun, Oct 4, 2015, 03:50 BST - UK Markets closed Budweiser owner ready to raise stakes with new £70bn takeover offer for rival brewer By Ben Martin | Telegraph – 8 hours ago 51.35 +1.05 
Carlos Brito and the InBev group he leads are said to be ready to clinch one of the biggest takeovers in corporate history 
The battle for the FTSE 100 brewer behind Peroni and Fosters is likely to intensify this week when Anheuser-Busch InBev, the owner of Stella Artois, is expected to make a sweetened approach to SABMiller (Xetra: BRW1.DE - news ) . 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) was revealed last month that the world’s biggest beer company had approached SAB about a deal to create a brewing giant that would be worth around $275bn (£181bn). 
• 'MegaBrew’ merger of biggest names in beer could be last blowout for tie-ups 
ABI, which also owns Budweiser, is understood to have started negotiations by testing the waters with a proposal of about £40 a share, which did not entice SAB. The talks, which are fluid, have since moved on but it is believed that ABI will improve its approach this week. 
Should ABI clinch the deal, it would be not only the biggest-ever takeover of a British company, but also the sixth-largest in corporate history. 
An offer of about £45 a share, which some City analysts are expecting, would value the FTSE 100 brewer at more than £70bn. The Takeover Panel has set a deadline of October 14 for ABI to make a formal offer or walk away, although that can be extended. 
Bosses at the Budweiser brewer, led by chief executive Carlos Brito, have been prolific dealmakers with a track record for moving quickly. It only took about five weeks for InBev to agree on a takeover with Anheuser-Busch in 2008. 
SAB’s two biggest shareholders, the tobacco company Altria, which owns the Marlboro brand, and Colombia’s Santo Domingo family are thought to be receptive to a deal with ABI at the right price. The stance of both shareholders is key, as between them they own about 41pc of the company. 
Since the ABI approach was announced in mid-September, both suitor and bid target have been silent about negotiations. Neither is obliged to update investors if ABI makes another takeover proposal this week. 
A deal between the two brewers has been rumoured for years and is highly anticipated by industry observers. 
SAB attempted to ward off a bid from ABI with an unsuccessful tilt at Heine-ken last year. When the Budweiser brewer finally made its approach last month it struck a conciliatory tone towards, saying its “intention is to work with SABMiller’s board toward a recommended transaction”. 
Spokesmen for both SAB and ABI declined to comment.
